Dear Mr. Bell:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
December 9, 2020. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the
contract and Modified Implementation Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP)
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for
each licensing statute and rule, Contract item, DHHS policy or MISEP section
citation, e.g. workers, supervisors, program managers, director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
implemented and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
o MiSACWIS users with access to the Book of Business, InfoView Reports
and the Monthly Child Welfare Management Report should incorporate the
use of these tools as well as other data management reports released by
the Department for continuous monitoring.
 Signature of the responsible party and date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are unrelated to
the staff person.
4

Four of thirty-five new employee files reviewed did not have all of the required
references documented in the file prior to the hire/start date. This involved three
intern students and one full time employee.
THIS IS A REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2019 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 1/24/2020.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has not
been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of child
abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where the person lived
in the 5 years preceding hire.
Two of thirty-five new employee files reviewed did not have documentation that the
agency received documentation that the individual was not on the Central Registry
prior to the hire/start date. This involved one full time employee and one student
intern. Both had a Central Registry clearance but after the hire/start date.
THIS IS A REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2019 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 1/24/2020.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance within
a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the staff
member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After the
initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted each
year.
Two of forty-three employee files reviewed did not have documentation of the
required written evaluation documented in the file. Both of these files were of new
employees.
THIS IS A REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2019 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 1/24/2020.

(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.

DHHS Policy Medical Passports
FOM 801 Page
11-13
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport containing all items listed in MCL
722.954c.
For children first entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided to the foster care provider within two
weeks of the child's placement date. The actual date the foster
care provider receive the medical passport must be documented
in MiSACWIS.
Updated Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.

DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development
FOM 722-08C
Page 2
The individual activities required by the foster parent/caregiver
to meet the specific individual needs of the child placed in their
home are included in the PATP. The foster parent/caregiver
must be included in the PATP process. The foster
parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates that the
foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
Additionally, the PATP details the services and activities
provided by the foster care worker to assist the foster
parent/caregiver in caring for the child.
9

Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and
service agreement, the parent is given a copy for review. Foster
care workers need to ensure the parent understands all areas
within the agreement. Parents and youths age 14 and older
must sign the PATP. If a parent or youth is unavailable or
refuses to sign the PATP, foster care workers must identify, and
document additional action needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and compliance
with the PATP. As the goals are achieved, modified, or
expanded, the updated PATP will reflect this process. Parents
and youths age 14 and older must participate in the
development of each updated treatment plan, allowing for
opportunity to evaluate their progress towards completing goals.
CI 17-096 Treatment Plan Signature Timeframes and
Documentation Requirements
When the treatment plan is completed, signatures for all
appropriate case members must be obtained. Signatures from
all appropriate case members, including youth ages 14 and
older for foster care and youth ages 11 and older for juvenile
justice, should be obtained before the corresponding court
hearing. All treatment plans with a report date of August 1,
2017, or later must have signatures from all appropriate case
members within 30 days of the report date.
One of four open Independent Living case files reviewed did not have
documentation of the youth’s signature as required. The youth signed the PATP, but
eight months late.
Seven of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation of
the youth, parent, or caregiver signature on the PATP as required. This involved one
missing youth signature, two missing parental signatures, and seven missing
caregiver signatures and. This also involved four late (beyond 30-days) parental
signatures and four late caregiver signatures.
THIS IS A REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2017 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 1/2/2018, THE 2018 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 1/11/2019 AND THE 2019 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 1/24/2020.

DHHS Policy Supervisory Approval - USP
FOM 722-09
Page 27

Case service plan approval process requires the foster care

DHHS Policy INDEPENDENT LIVING PREPARATION
FOM 722-03C
Page 1-3
Independent living preparation is required for all youth in foster
care age 14 and older, regardless of their permanency planning
goal. Once the youth is age 14, the Parent Agency Treatment
Plan must describe the services provided and goals for future
services, which will help the youth prepare for functional
independence. The goal of independent living preparation is to
assist youth in transitioning to self-sufficiency. Independent
living preparation activities for youth aged 12-13 years are
encouraged based upon availability of services and assessment
of need.
Note: Provision of services does not equate to achievement of
permanency. Reasonable efforts to finalize a permanency plan
within a timely manner must still be provided; see FOM 722-07,
Permanency Planning - Overview, for all permanency planning
goal requirements.
Two of four open Independent Living case files reviewed did not have
documentation of the efforts to prepare the youth for independent living.
Documentation was present but occurred eleven months after placement into ILP.
DHHS Policy Permanency Pact
FOM 722-07F
page 8-9
The Permanency Pact is a free tool created by Foster Club that
is designed to encourage life-long, kin-like connections between
a young person and a supportive adult.
Review the Permanency Pact with the youth and the
supportive adult(s)/relative caregiver.
Complete the Permanency Pact Certificate with the youth and
supportive adult(s)/relative caregiver.
Provide a copy to each participant, upload a copy to the
Documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS, and include the original
agreement in the permanency plan approval packet.
• DHS-347, Permanency Goal Approval.
The assigned caseworker must complete this form.
13

Upload a copy to the Documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS and
attach the original as the cover sheet to the permanency plan
approval packet.
• Independent Living Plan, if applicable.
Note: If independent living will be the youth's living
arrangement, then a detailed independent living plan must be
submitted with the permanency goal approval packet; see FOM
722-03C, Preparation and Placement of Older Youth, for
detailed information on independent living plans.
Two of four open Independent Living case files reviewed did not have
documentation of the Permanency Pact being completed as required.
DHHS Policy Adoption Assessment Addendum
ADM 300 (Page
4)
CHILD ADOPTION ASSESSMENT ADDENDUM
The DHHS-606, Child Adoption Assessment Addendum, must
be used to update the DHHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment,
on an annual basis if the child has not been placed for adoption
and when there is a change in placement or another significant
event. The addendum must reflect significant changes and child
development updates from the previous assessment. The
addendum must provide current information that would be
significant to a prospective adoptive family.
Contracted adoption agencies must forward a copy of the child
assessment addendum to the local DHHS adoption monitor
within five calendar days of completion, for inclusion in the
child’s permanent record.
Distribution
The adoption worker or assigned DHHS monitor must provide a
copy of the child assessment addendum to the foster care
worker.
Two of eight Adoption case files reviewed did not have the DHHS-606 completed in
a timely manner. The first case had the DHHS-606 completed three months after the
child moved and the second case file had the DHHS-606 completed four months
after the adoption assessment.
DHHS Policy Quarterly Adoption Progress Report OVERVIEW
ADM 330 (Page
1)
Adoption workers must submit written quarterly progress reports
using the DHHS-614, Quarterly Adoption Progress Report. The
adoption worker must have at least one face-to-face contact
with the child during each quarter prior to the adoption
supervision period for the purpose of completing the DHHS-614.
14

The child assessment may serve as the initial quarterly report if
it is completed within the required quarterly reporting period and
attached to the DHHS-614 form.
Two of eight Adoption case files reviewed did not have the quarterly progress report
completed as required. The first case file had four quarterly reports still in progress
and not approved. The second case file three quarterly reports completed until 3, 2,
and 2 months late.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Several of the employee files reviewed had documentation of the “employee
check list” present but the form was blank. It was discussed that this would
not provide the needed documentation to ensure that the appropriate
orientation had taken place.
 Several coding issues of uploaded documentation were found. The agency
was not coding (labeling) each document the same each time. The agency
agreed that this has been a concern and they will develop a method to ensure
this is corrected in the future.
 Two of the special evaluations reviewed did not have documentation of the
agency’s procedure for monitoring the progress of the foster parents efforts to
complete the corrective action plan. In the first, the foster parents were not
able to schedule the required training for several months but there was no
action documented that would take place to ensure safety for the children
during that time. The second involved a similar situation and there was no
documentation of the agency monitoring until the task was completed. The
agency agreed and will develop the monitoring aspect in their corrective
action plans.
 Several service plans of youth in the refugee program had reports present
and the only documentation in the worker signature section was “CM no
longer works at the BCS”. It was discussed that a supervisor should have
signed the reports, with a manager approving, rather than having no worker
signature.
 Several social work contacts between the worker, youth and foster parents
did not identified the foster parents as participants; however, they were
identified in the narrative. The agency reported that they have been leaving
this information out because when the bio-parents get a copy of the report
they also gain the foster parents names. Different ways of resolving this issue
were discussed and the agency will seek a solution.
15

 One of the closed files in the refugee program did not have the discharge
report completed within 30-days however, because this is not a state
contracted program, no violation was found, and technical assistance was
provided.
 Two employee files reviewed did not have dates on the references within the
file. This was brought to discussion and the agency will examine ways of
developing a system of checking for dates on all documents.
 A significant majority of adoption family assessments reviewed indicated they
were unable to make a recommendation due to missing documents. This is
an unusually high percentage. Rule 605 outlines everything that is to be
included in the evaluation. If any pieces are missing after diligent and
documented efforts, then the report can indicate such, but this should be the
rare exception. This issue was discussed, and the agency will look into
making changes in this area.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following area:
 The agency informed the consultant that they no longer had a full-time individual
conducting compliance inspections with the agency. It was suggested that this is
a position that they would need to maintain in order to ensure that the action
steps of their upcoming CAP are completed. This would also ensure that they are
following the guidelines of their accreditation. The agency agreed to examine
ways of ensuring that this position is filled.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
Currently there are two active special investigations which have not be concluded:
16

The first active special investigation (2021C0212002) was initiated on 10/13/20 and
involves the following allegations. It is alleged that a youth in the agency’s care was
not given his personal gaming system when he was replaced to a residential setting.
This allegation is currently under investigation and no corrective plan is required at
this time.
The second active special investigation (2021C0212004) was initiated on 10/16/20
and involves the following allegations. It is alleged that the agency placed the
daughter of a refugee foster child into a guardianship when the foster child did not
have the legal competency to consent to the guardianship. This allegation is
currently under investigation and no corrective plan is required at this time.
The single required corrective action plan involved the agency’s 2019 Annual
licensing inspection.
Staff Interviews:
Several interviews were conducted with staff ranging from the Chief Administrator to
Foster Care Case Managers. Each reporting that the agency is supplying their
needs to work in the COVID-19 environment in a safe way. They also report that
many of their social work contacts are completed virtually but that they are able to
keep up with the needs of their families and youth. All worker report that their
supervisors are knowledgeable and keep in a high level of communication with
them. They feel supported and believe that the agency is working in the best interest
of the families and youth. All interviewed agreed that it has been difficult during the
COVID-19 pandemic, but they have been able to meet the demands of the families
and youth.

analyst interviewed/visited seven families, and all indicated being very satisfied with
the services being provided by the agency.
